text:
```def process_market_book(self, market, market_book):
                total_live_trade_count = 0
                for runner in runner_list:
                    runner_data = strategy.get_runner_context(market_id=market_book.market_id,
                        selection_id=runner['selection_id'],
                                handicap=runner['handicap'])
                    live_trade_count = runner_data.live_trade_count
                    print({'selection_id': runner['selection_id'], 'runner_name': runner['runner_name'], 'live_trade_count': live_trade_count})
                    total_live_trade_count = total_live_trade_count + live_trade_count

                if total_live_trade_count == 0:
                    for runner in runner_list:
                        if 'price' not in runner.keys():
                            pass

                        else:
                            price = runner['price']
                            if price > absolute_min_price and price < absolute_max_price:
                                stake = 2

                                trade = Trade(
                                    market_id=market_book.market_id,
                                    selection_id=runner['selection_id'],
                                    handicap=runner['handicap'],
                                    strategy=strategy,
                                    notes=runner
                                )
                                order = trade.create_order(
                                    side="LAY", order_type=LimitOrder(price=price, size=stake, persistence_type=persistence_type)
                                )
                                self.place_order(market, order)```

The indents came out a bit weird there, but that's essentially it for now, its a super simple script, just familiarising myself with Flumine at the mo (runner_list is just a list of dicts with runner info)

text: Thanks <@U4H19D1D2>, if you let us know please what TPD say (and would you mind also confirming when the feeds look correct too?) Cheers

elements.text: Thanks
, if you let us know please what TPD say (and would you mind also confirming when the feeds look correct too?) Cheers

text:
`Yes, its due to the use of "Bangor-on-Dee" instead of "Bangor" and is causing mapping failures at our side.

The change was made to the venue name to fix a different feed related issue but we don't yet have dual mapping (for both Bangor & Bangor-on-Dee) on the GPS API from our side so the data won't be coming through for todays Bangor meeting.  This will be addressed as part of the current ongoing GPS API v2 work and I expect this to be in place in time for the next Bangor-on-Dee meeting on the 30th September.`

elements.text:

This will be addressed as part of the current ongoing GPS API v2 work and I expect this to be in place in time for the next Bangor-on-Dee meeting on the 30th September.`

text:
All this talk of gps issues makes me wonder if it's actually reliable enough to be used for triggering bets? In particular, this is concerning:

`How accurate is the live data?
Accuracy is recorded as the difference between the official finish time and the GPS derived finish time, 
the BHA defined conversion between time and length varies by ground and code between 4 and 6 
lengths per second, taking speed = 5.5ls-1 and L=2.4m, and a standard deviation of a sample of the 
data measured as 100ms, then 95% of the live data is within 2.59m of the true position.`

...considering that there are often multiple runners within a 2.59m section. I would imagine GPS could easily be reporting positions in the wrong order? And that's only 95% of the time. The other 5% must be a monumental fuckup, particularly where all the runners are tightly bunched?

data measured as 100ms, then 95% of the live data is within 2.59m of the true position.

...considering that there are often multiple runners within a 2.59m section. I would imagine GPS could easily be reporting positions in the wrong order? And that's only 95% of the time. The other 5% must be a monumental fuckup, particularly where all the runners are tightly bunched?

text: It can be done and a few of us have been using it very successfully for some time now. That said; I have the impression some people imagine it to be a bit easier than it really is. A lot of new people are now getting it and they're not all seasoned pros - it will be interesting to see how they fare over time and what effect that might have on those of us who've been at it for a while. So far the increased take up doesn't seem to have harmed me at all, but time will tell.

elements.text: It can be done and a few of us have been using it very successfully for some time now. That said; I have the impression some people imagine it to be a bit easier than it really is. A lot of new people are now getting it and they're not all seasoned pros - it will be interesting to see how they fare over time and what effect that might have on those of us who've been at it for a while. So far the increased take up doesn't seem to have harmed me at all, but time will tell.

text: TPD provide historic data BUT it's not a reproduction of what you would have received live as they apply some transformations after the fact to try to make the positions more accurate. As a result I've found it largely useless for backtesting and this seems to be a barrier to entry that protects the guys who have been doing it since the beginning and have collected their own data... on the flip side, they would have had zero historic data having started from the beginning and have done very well for themselves

text: <@UBS7QANF3> so they edit the feed after the race to cover up their inaccuracies. Seems pointless to me. Bit like the "pro" tipsters who post their results after the race and use the best price that was available.

elements.text: so they edit the feed after the race to cover up their inaccuracies. Seems pointless to me. Bit like the "pro" tipsters who post their results after the race and use the best price that was available.

text: Sort of... the aim of their historic feed is not to provide an accurate recording of the live data but to provide the most accurate positions possible. This still has value from e.g. more accurate sectional timing. TPD is aware that there is demand for the kind of historic data we'd need for backtesting and have made noises that they are working on it but I'm not expecting it any time soon

text: I guess that at some point in the future, the edge will dwindle as more and more people adopt the GPS feeds...IF they are able to implement it correctly. Surprised that Betfair don't have a similar API to be honest.

elements.text: I guess that at some point in the future, the edge will dwindle as more and more people adopt the GPS feeds...IF they are able to implement it correctly. Surprised that Betfair don't have a similar API to be honest.

text: Similar to? Betfair has a number of TPD licenses that they give out (for free). It's accessed in a very similar way to the other Betfair streams. Pretty much everyone on here talking about using the GPS data is getting it through Betfair rather than direct from TPD

text: <@U016TGY3676> - It does seem reasonable to expect the edges to dwindle, but that hasn't happened with BF market data so maybe not...? I've kept a track on how much value was available on the TPD markets from the most obvious strategies since I first had it (over 2 years now). There was quite a steep fall off at the start but now I think it's quite stable. It is widely believed that edges on BF disappear over time but my experience does not reflect this.

text: Edges do disappear when something fundamental changes - like when XM was introduced, but I don't find that they 'fall off' much at all.

text: I think these kind of edges are more robust than you might think... not everyone is doing the same thing, it takes time for new entrants to get up and running and the experienced guys have multiple years headstart to know what works, what doesn't and the nuances of the data
